At some point in tank evolution the viewing slits were replaced with periscopes. But tanks ride rough and you get tossed around inside. So how do you make a periscope that you don't have to put your eyes against, especially while moving over rough terrain? 

Destin probably has it figured out by now. You use prism mirrors to redirect the image inside the tank and make it visible in a larger viewing area.

interesting. was that new information to you? how about this, back in the day it was actually referred to as the T-34-76 and was shortened for teaching purposes

Sure it is, but fact remains it is a "T-34". The 85mm main gun and modded turret doesn't change the tank itself, hence its position in the name, the "85" follows the original identification. ( if it had a 122mm cannon on it, it is now called a "T-34-122" <- which is a real thing.

Now I mean no disrespect to yourself, however I did want to make it clear ( Back him up ) that he is correct. I felt the need to say this because you said "actually" implying that the information was incorrect.

Most soldiers of all armies fought bravely, but most were unwilling to waste their lives. Unless spectacularly well led, Italians fighting in North Africa would often surrender their inferior tanks unless the they were interspersed with well trained German troops with high esprit de corp. The French, early in the war, had some very good equipment. Unfortunately, they dispersed their tanks in small units to support infantry and were outmaneuvered. French high command fought WW I style, not WW II.

At a local fair the police had an exhibition with their armoured vehicle, a futuristic-looking amphibious type thing. What was really interesting is that what looked like the windshield from the inside (about 3 inches high) was actually a periscope. It obviously had thick armoured glass, but still I thought it was a pretty ingenious way to protect the crew without losing visibility.

@destinws2 it is if you like the sqeak of metal tracks, the rumble of the high power engine, the invincible feeling of being in an armored vehicle, the ability to traverse most types of terrain (within reason), and of course having a HUGE cannon on top of your "car"
